title: 113_hr5330
content: The Act is known as the "Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act" or the "BUILD Act." It makes Build America Bonds permanent and introduces Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds for certain cities. The "Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act" amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new period for tax credits. The credit percentage to bondholders is reduced under this amendment. The bond issued during calendar years 2014 and thereafter will have decreasing applicable percentages for bondholders. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act extends payments to issuers, amending the Internal Revenue Code. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act amends the Internal Revenue Code by changing the dates for qualified bonds and reducing the percentage of payments to issuers. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act amends the Internal Revenue Code by changing dates for qualified bonds and reducing payment percentages to issuers. The Secretary will determine the applicable percentage according to a specified table. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act changes dates for qualified bonds and reduces payment percentages to issuers. The applicable percentage for qualified bonds issued during specific calendar years is specified in a table. Additionally, a special rule is introduced for Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds for certain cities. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act introduces changes for qualified bonds, including reduced payment percentages and adjusted dates. It also includes a special rule for certain cities regarding economic development extension bonds, with an applicable percentage of 35 percent. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act amends qualified bonds, with reduced payment percentages and adjusted dates. It includes a special rule for certain cities on economic development extension bonds, with a 35 percent applicable percentage. The act specifies conditions for the use of funds for qualified purposes and requires an irrevocable election by the issuer. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act allows for economic development extension bonds with a 35 percent applicable percentage for specified cities meeting certain criteria. The Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act allows for economic development extension bonds with specific criteria for specified cities, including a poverty rate of at least 150 percent of the national rate or a population loss of 20 percent between 2000 and 2010. There is a limitation on the amount of bonds that can be designated for each city. The Secretary allocates bond limitation to specified cities based on population proportion. Economic development extension bonds are treated as qualified bonds under the Bringing Urgent Investment to Local Development Act. The applicable percentage for qualified bonds under subsection (b) is 35 percent. Current refunding bonds are permitted under subsection (g) of section 54AA, with specific criteria for refunding bonds to be considered qualified bonds. The refunding bond must not exceed the outstanding amount of the refunded bond and the refunded bond must be redeemed within 90 days of the refunding bond issuance. The applicable percentage for such bonds is the lowest specified in section 6431(b). Average maturity is determined according to section 147(b)(2)(A) and issuance restrictions do not apply. In case of sequestration, payments to issuers under section 6431(b) of the Internal Revenue Code will be increased to offset the percentage reduction. Sequestration refers to a reduction in direct spending ordered by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. The report prepared by the Director of the Office of Management and Budget in accordance with the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 or the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010 specifies that the amendments made by this section will apply to obligations issued on or after the enactment date of the Act.
